metadata.titleEn: Ground observation dataset of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index and plant height at Daman station in the middle reaches of Heihe River (growth period in 2016)
metadata.description: This dataset is a continuous ground observation data of vegetation coverage (%), biomass (g/plant), leaf area index (LAI) and plant height (cm) of seed corn during the growing period in 2016 at Daman Station ( 38.85551N,100.37223E)in the middle reaches of the Heihe River. Ground observation was carried out in three sample plots.  Biomass observation included fresh and dry aboveground biomass, fresh and dry underground biomass (fresh and dry root weight), vegetation coverage was observed by digital camera, leaf area index was observed by LAI 2200, and plant height was observed by tape measure. The observation period was from May 19 to September 5, 2016, in which LAI started from May 30. Observation parameters were observed every 5 days before July 31 and every 10 days thereafter, and a total of 18 observations (LAI was 9) were carried out during the whole growing period. The dataset can provide data basis for inversion and validation of surface vegetation parameters.
metadata.instructions: Observation data are stored in Excel form. The file name is yyyy.xlsm, where yyyy stands for year.

background: Crop biomass is one of the most important biophysical indicators of crop growth. The accurate and efficient estimation of the regional crop biomass at different growth stages is of great importance in guiding crop management decision making, such as in effective fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. In addition, as an important aspect of biomass energy, the accurate estimation of crop biomass contributes to the rational and effective utilization of biomass energy. Moreover, effective estimates of crop biomass during the growing season could play a key role in crop yield prediction. The traditional crop biomass estimation method is mainly based on field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting. The traditional methods are relatively accurate, but they are labor intensive and time consuming. Moreover, the sparse nature of space makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Thus, it is impossible to acquire the regional crop biomass via ground measurements alone. The satellite remote sensing technique is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. Previous studies have revealed that remote sensing is a reliable and effective technique to obtain biophysical and biochemical crop information.
research objective: In this paper, four machine learning models, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were adopted to estimate the seasonal corn biomass based on field observation data and moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data from 2012 to 2019 in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China.
challenges: This is currently one of the major challenges for agricultural researchers and farm managers.
methods: In this study, the corn biomass was estimated based on daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, and four machine learning algorithms, namely RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, were adopted to predict the biomass. Large, relatively homogeneous areas, which mainly functioned as corn growing areas, were selected as the sample sites. According to a field survey of the sample sites, a total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m. All selected plants in each plot were collected, and the roots of the corn plants were washed. The fresh weight was measured, after which the plants were transported to the laboratory, chopped into easy-to-dry segments, and dried in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 h until a constant dry biomass was obtained. MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. The forward feature selection method was implemented to choose the most influential variables, which is an iterative method starting from the condition of no model features. In each iteration, we add a given feature that best improves the model until the addition of a new variable does not further improve the model performance. The RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost algorithms were adopted in this study. R software was used to implement the above four machine learning algorithms with the randomForest, kernlab, brnn, and xgboost packages. In this study, the caret package in R software was applied to tune the parameters of the above four machine learning algorithms. The 10-fold cross validation method was implemented to evaluate the performance of the above four machine learning models due to the small number of training samples.
dataset: MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. A total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m.
findings: The results indicated that the corn biomass was suitably estimated (the coefficient of determination (R2) was between 0.72 and 0.78) with the four machine learning models. The XGBoost model performed better than the other three models (R2 = 0.78, root mean squared error (RMSE) = 2.86 t/ha and mean absolute error (MAE) = 1.86 t/ha). Moreover, the RF model was an effective method (R2 = 0.77, RMSE = 2.91 t/ha and MAE = 1.91 t/ha), with a performance comparable to that of the XGBoost model.

Verification.Question: Is the digital camera photo method used for observing vegetation coverage in ground-based data collection?

Disjunctive.Question: Which method is more commonly used for measuring leaf area index in field observations: LAI 2200, digital photography, or satellite remote sensing?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are sample sites for field measurement selected in the Heihe River Basin?
Concept Completion.Answer: large relatively homogeneous areas mainly functioning as corn growing areas

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are associated with crop biomass estimation in the Heihe River Basin?
Concept Completion.Answer: labor-intensive and time-consuming nature of traditional field measurement methods

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for estimating crop biomass in agricultural research?
Example.Answer: In the field of agricultural research, a data collection method for estimating crop biomass involves field measurements such as destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing. This traditional method, although accurate, is labor-intensive and time-consuming. In contrast, satellite remote sensing techniques, such as using MODIS reflectance data, offer a more efficient and comprehensive approach to monitor crop biomass over large areas.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when collecting data for crop biomass estimation in large-scale agricultural studies?
Example.Answer: One of the challenges in collecting data for crop biomass estimation in large-scale agricultural studies is the sparse nature of space, which makes it difficult to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales using ground measurements alone. This limitation highlights the need for satellite remote sensing techniques to compensate for the deficiencies of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of data collection methods for estimating crop biomass in agricultural research?
Feature Specification.Answer: field measurements, destructive sampling, laboratory drying, weighing, satellite remote sensing, high spatial coverage, long time series data, ground observations, machine learning models

Feature Specification.Question: What are the attributes of machine learning models used for predicting corn biomass based on remote sensing and field data?
Feature Specification.Answer: RF, SVM, ANN, XGBoost, integrate field observation data with satellite reflectance data, parameter tuning, 10-fold cross-validation, feature selection methods, identify influential variables, improve model accuracy

Quantification.Question: How many times were ground observations conducted during the 2016 corn growing season in the Heihe River basin?
Over how many years were MODIS datasets analyzed for corn biomass estimation in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin?
How many sample sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019 in the Heihe River basin study?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'vegetation coverage observation method' in the context of data collection for crop biomass?
Definition.Answer: In this context, 'vegetation coverage observation method' refers to the use of digital camera photography to capture and analyze the percentage of ground covered by vegetation within a specified area. This method provides a visual and quantitative assessment of plant coverage, which is a crucial parameter in understanding crop growth and health.

Definition.Question: What does 'remote sensing technique' mean in relation to crop biomass monitoring?
Definition.Answer: In relation to crop biomass monitoring, 'remote sensing technique' refers to the use of satellite-based tools to collect data on vegetation parameters over large areas. It provides high spatial coverage and long-term data series, allowing researchers to overcome the limitations of traditional field measurements and to estimate crop biomass more comprehensively and repetitively.

Comparison.Question: How does the accuracy and efficiency of estimating crop biomass using machine learning models with MODIS data compare to traditional field-based methods?
Comparison.Answer: Traditional field-based methods are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming, while machine learning models using MODIS data offer a repeatable and efficient approach with high spatial coverage, effectively compensating for traditional methods' limitations. The machine learning models achieved suitable accuracy with a coefficient of determination (R2) between 0.72 and 0.78.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of regional crop biomass estimation differ when using ground measurements versus satellite remote sensing data?
Comparison.Answer: Ground measurements face challenges related to labor intensity and limited spatial coverage, making it difficult to obtain regional scale data. Satellite remote sensing data provides extensive spatial coverage and valuable vegetation parameter information, addressing the spatial limitations of ground measurements but may face challenges in accuracy that are dependent on model selection and data quality.

Interpretation.Question: How might the different temporal frequencies of data collection impact the accuracy of biomass estimation models for crops?
Interpretation.Answer: The temporal frequency of data collection can significantly impact the accuracy of biomass estimation models. In the context of the field above, ground observations were conducted with varying frequencies, initially every 5 days and then every 10 days. Such variations can influence the models' ability to accurately capture the growth dynamics of crops like corn, particularly in relation to critical growth stages that might be missed with less frequent data collection. Additionally, the integration of satellite remote sensing data, which provides consistent long-term coverage, helps to complement ground observations and improve overall model accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using traditional field measurement techniques for crop biomass estimation compared to remote sensing methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Traditional field measurement techniques for crop biomass estimation, such as destructive sampling and laboratory drying, are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and limited in spatial coverage. These methods do not provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales, which can be a significant limitation for researchers and farm managers. In contrast, remote sensing methods offer repeatable monitoring with high spatial coverage and long time series, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods by providing valuable information on vegetation parameters over large areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for integrating ground observation data with satellite remote sensing data in estimating crop biomass?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of ground observation data with satellite remote sensing data is necessitated by the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods, which are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and spatially sparse, making it impossible to acquire comprehensive regional crop biomass. Satellite remote sensing provides valuable information on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series, effectively compensating for these deficiencies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors drive the selection of specific machine learning algorithms in crop biomass estimation studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of specific machine learning algorithms in crop biomass estimation studies is driven by their performance in handling the complexity of the data, ability to produce accurate predictions, and adaptability to the available datasets. In the discussed context, algorithms like XGBoost and RF were chosen because they showed high accuracy and effectiveness in estimating corn biomass, as indicated by their performance metrics.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing satellite remote sensing techniques on the efficiency of crop biomass estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques can significantly enhance the efficiency of crop biomass estimation by providing valuable information on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series. This method effectively compensates for the deficiencies of traditional biomass estimation methods, which are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and spatially limited.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of using a forward feature selection method on the performance of machine learning models in estimating crop biomass?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The forward feature selection method enhances the performance of machine learning models by iteratively adding features that improve the model until no further improvement is observed. This method contributes to effectively selecting influential variables, thereby improving the accuracy and reliability of the biomass estimation models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate machine learning algorithms with remote sensing data to estimate crop biomass in agricultural research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating machine learning algorithms with remote sensing data is important because it allows for the estimation of regional crop biomass across different growth stages, which is crucial for crop management decision-making and biomass energy utilization. Satellite remote sensing provides valuable vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series data, which effectively compensates for the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods that are labor-intensive and time-consuming.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of adopting multiple machine learning models for predicting seasonal corn biomass in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of adopting multiple machine learning models, such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, is to identify the most effective approach for predicting seasonal corn biomass. By evaluating different models, researchers aim to optimize the prediction accuracy and performance, thus contributing to better resource management and decision support in agriculture. The use of diverse models allows for a comprehensive assessment of their capabilities in handling the complex relationships between biomass and various input variables.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific data collection techniques employed to estimate crop biomass using remote sensing and ground observations in agricultural research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using satellite remote sensing for broad spatial coverage and long-term monitoring, combined with field measurements such as destructive sampling and laboratory drying. Ground observations include measuring fresh and dry weights of plant biomass, while remote sensing utilizes MODIS reflectance data to capture vegetation parameters. The integration of these methods helps overcome the limitations of traditional field-based measurements.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methodologies enable the accurate estimation of crop biomass during different growth stages?
Enablement.Answer: The use of traditional field measurements combined with satellite remote sensing techniques enables accurate estimation. Field measurements involve destructive sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing, while remote sensing techniques like MODIS provide high spatial coverage and long time series data on vegetation parameters.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methods enable the selection of the most influential variables for crop biomass prediction using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The forward feature selection method enables the identification of the most influential variables by iteratively adding features that best improve model performance. This approach, combined with machine learning algorithms, helps in selecting relevant variables from remote sensing data for accurate biomass prediction.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional field measurement methods be insufficient for comprehensive regional biomass estimation?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional field measurement methods, while accurate, are labor-intensive and time-consuming. They are limited by the sparse nature of spatial data collection, making it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. These limitations necessitate alternative approaches such as satellite remote sensing techniques, which offer high spatial coverage and long time series data.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to use both ground observations and remote sensing data in estimating crop biomass?
Expectation.Answer: Ground observations provide detailed and accurate biophysical measurements, while remote sensing data offer extensive spatial coverage and temporal frequency. Combining these data sources enables a more comprehensive and accurate estimation of crop biomass, effectively compensating for the limitations of using either method alone.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand what challenges exist in using machine learning models for estimating crop biomass.
Assertion.Answer: One of the major challenges in using machine learning models for estimating crop biomass is the sparse nature of space, which makes it difficult to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales using traditional methods. Additionally, the small number of training samples necessitates careful model validation, such as using 10-fold cross-validation, to ensure accurate and reliable predictions.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the process of selecting the most influential variables for crop biomass estimation models.
Assertion.Answer: The process of selecting the most influential variables for crop biomass estimation models involves using a forward feature selection method. This iterative approach starts with no model features and adds features that best improve the model's performance, continuing until the addition of new variables no longer enhances the model, ensuring that only the most impactful variables are used.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the traditional and modern data collection methods used for estimating crop biomass and discuss their respective advantages and disadvantages.
Request/Directive.Answer: Traditional crop biomass estimation methods include field measurements such as destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing. These methods are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming, and they cannot provide comprehensive regional data. Modern methods involve satellite remote sensing techniques, which offer high spatial coverage and long time series data, effectively compensating for the limitations of traditional methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be integrated with existing field observation data to enhance crop biomass estimation accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products, which provide valuable information on vegetation parameters. Integrating these datasets with field observation data and applying machine learning models can significantly enhance the accuracy of crop biomass estimation.
